response.answer_text: Unpopular Opinion: Why PayPal Enabling Bitcoin Purchases Isn’t All Positive PayPal, the $250 billion payments conglomerate, is allowing its users to buy and sell Bitcoin, along with other crypto assets. While the general sentiment remains positive, industry experts are dissatisfied.  PayPal launches new service enabling users to buy, hold and sell cryptocurrency, including Bitcoin. SOPA Images/Light Rocket via Getty Images In an official announcement, PayPal president and CEO Dan Schulman confirmed that the platform would allow the buying and selling of cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin. It would also enable cryptocurrency payments for 26 million merchants, enabling cryptocurrencies to finance digital commerce. PayPal supporting Bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies undoubtedly buoy the image of the sector and the asset class. It further strengthens the perception of Bitcoin as an established store of value and cryptocurrencies as recognized assets. But one issue is that PayPal’s integration of crypto assets comes with a catch. At least in the near term, it would not allow users that buy crypto on PayPal to transfer outside of their accounts. In the future, PayPal could allow users to transfer Bitcoin from one account to another but in the immediate future, it won’t be supported. Jake Chervinsky, general counsel at Compound Finance, said the inability of users to transfer the crypto they purchase in the foreseeable future is the “highlight” of the news. “This is the highlight of the PayPal news for me. They're not only preventing withdrawals to self-custody, they won't even allow transfers between accounts. I'd be glad to speak with PayPal 's legal team about why these restrictions aren't required for regulatory compliance.” Since users cannot withdraw Bitcoin they purchase from their PayPal accounts to other accounts for now, some industry executives have started to question if that would still be considered Bitcoin. In essence, PayPal’s integration of crypto assets is similar to purchasing assets on Revolut and Robin-hood. Users that purchase Bitcoin on PayPal can get exposure to BTC, but not move the BTC out of the platform or other addresses, for now. “Look, I understand the temptation to just be excited about PayPal & ignore the fact that they prohibit transfers to other accounts & withdrawals to self-custody. But if you can't hold your own keys, is it even Bitcoin? How much will we sacrifice in the name of ‘number go up?’” Chervinsky added. PlanB, the creator of the Stock-to-Flow (S2F) model, echoed a similar stance. Initially, the analyst was optimistic about the PayPal integration. But, he emphasized that users cannot directly move the Bitcoin they purchase on the platform. “OK, we can forget this Paypal PYPL ‘news.’ ‘Crypto in [the Paypal] account cannot be transferred to other accounts on or off PayPal.’ So, this is all a big PayPal nothing burger, just entries in a central PayPal database, nothing to do with bitcoin,” he said. Ripple CEO Brad Garlinghouse similarly said that the PayPal news is overall optimistic, but it is taking two steps forward and one step backward. “2 steps forward, 1 step back…Great to see a payment pioneer leaning in, BUT disappointing some fundamental tenets / benefits of crypto are spurned. I suspect PayPal is concerned about the (wait for it…) regulatory uncertainty, impacting its roll-out on a number of levels,” Garlinghouse noted.
